image.altText: A group of people cheering and celebrating

image.altText: Aerial view of a bushfire at night time

title.children: Army major tells bushfire inquiry he may not have approved 'whiz break' that led to massive blaze

items.synopsis: Acclaimed French artist, author and former partner of Pablo Picasso, Françoise Gilot, dies age 101.

title.children: French painter who loved — and later left — Picasso, dies aged 101

image.altText: Headshot photo of smiling Andrew Heard.

items.synopsis: The grim details of a fatal crocodile attack on a fisherman in Far North Queensland have been revealed following a coronial investigation into his death.

title.children: Fisherman's death first known case of two crocodiles consuming a human, department finds

image.altText: A decrepit small one-storey building with pale yellow paint peeling off

image.altText: A person wearing black gloves and a hooded jacket uses a screwdriver to unscrew a number plate.

title.children: Thieves are targeting number plates — how can you protect yours from being stolen?

image.altText: Empty retail strip in Sydney CBD, artistic shot from low down along pavement.

items.synopsis: Australia's economy is close to stall speed, with growth disappointing in the March quarter. RBA governor Philip Lowe defends the bank's decision to raise rates yesterday. Follow the day's events and send your questions to our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Your questions answered as economic growth stalls while RBA governor defends rate hike, ASX treads water

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The administrators of weight loss firm Jenny Craig have recommended that the business be wound up because they couldn't find a buyer. Jenny Craig's 91 stores in Australia and New Zealand have closed and staff will be made redundant. FTI Consulting say they were unable to find a buyer for the business despite 15 interested parties, four of whom submitted offers. They will recommend to creditors that the business be liquidated at a creditors' meeting next week. Jenny Craig's online business will be sold to healthcare technology company Eucalyptus. "Despite best efforts, the administrators were unable to find a buyer for the physical stores and employees of the  Australian and New Zealand business," the administrators said. " The administrators have today advised all of the employees in Australia New  Zealand that a sale of the business with the stores continuing to trade and staff continuing their employment has  not been achievable." " This has resulted in a decision to immediately cease trading from stores and employees being  made redundant, which is an unfortunate outcome and one which the administrators had sought to avoid." FTI were called in as voluntary liquidators last month to try and sell the Australian and New Zealand business. Jenny Craig's US business went under last month. Here's more from business reporter Rhianna Whitson.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jenny Craig closes down

featuredLink.title: Jenny Craig collapses in Australia and New Zealand after no buyer found for weight-loss company

children.content: The administrators of weight loss firm Jenny Craig have recommended that the business be wound up because they couldn't find a buyer.
Jenny Craig's 91 stores in Australia and New Zealand have closed and staff will be made redundant.
FTI Consulting say they were unable to find a buyer for the business despite 15 interested parties, four of whom submitted offers.
They will recommend to creditors that the business be liquidated at a creditors' meeting next week.
Jenny Craig's online business will be sold to healthcare technology company Eucalyptus.
"Despite best efforts, the administrators were unable to find a buyer for the physical stores and employees of the  Australian and New Zealand business," the administrators said.

" The administrators have today advised all of the employees in Australia New  Zealand that a sale of the business with the stores continuing to trade and staff continuing their employment has  not been achievable."
" This has resulted in a decision to immediately cease trading from stores and employees being  made redundant, which is an unfortunate outcome and one which the administrators had sought to avoid."
FTI were called in as voluntary liquidators last month to try and sell the Australian and New Zealand business.
Jenny Craig's US business went under last month.
Here's more from business reporter Rhianna Whitson.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Commonwealth Bank has updated its rate forecasts in light of yesterday's RBA decision to raise the cash rate to 4.1% and today's speech by Philip Lowe. CBA's head of Australian economics Gareth Aird said his team now expects one further cash rate rise to 4.35%, most likely at the August meeting, but with the possibility of it coming as soon as next month. He says there's a risk the RBA will make it four hikes in a row, with moves in July and August (to follow up on the rises in May and June) taking the cash rate to a possible peak of 4.6%. CBA has also pushed back the forecast timing of interest rate cuts, from the last quarter of this year to the first quarter of next, but tips 1.25 percentage points of reductions next year to take the cash rate target to 3.1 per cent by the end of 2024. Mr Aird also upped the odds of Australia sliding into recession, based on these latest forecasts. "The Australian economy contracted on a per capita basis in Q1 23 [first quarter 2023] and we expect a per capita recession to be confirmed in the Q2 23 national accounts. "A recession now looks a distinct possibility in H2 23 [second half 2023] and we put the chance at 50%."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: CBA now tips further rate rise, or rises

children.content: The Commonwealth Bank has updated its rate forecasts in light of yesterday's RBA decision to raise the cash rate to 4.1% and today's speech by Philip Lowe.
CBA's head of Australian economics Gareth Aird
said his team now
expects one further cash rate rise to 4.35%
, most likely at the August meeting, but with the possibility of it coming as soon as next month.
He says there's a risk the RBA will make it four hikes in a row, with moves in July and August (to follow up on the rises in May and June) taking the
cash rate to a
possible peak of 4.6%
CBA has also pushed back the forecast timing of interest rate cuts, from the last quarter of this year to the first quarter of next, but
tips 1.25 percentage points of reductions next year
to take the
cash rate target to 3.1 per cent by the end of 2024
Mr Aird also upped the odds of Australia sliding into recession, based on these latest forecasts.
"The Australian economy contracted on a per capita basis in Q1 23 [first quarter 2023] and we expect a per capita recession to be confirmed in the Q2 23 national accounts.
"A recession now looks a distinct possibility in H2 23 [second half 2023] and we put the chance at 50%."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Let's take a look at some news other than Australia's economy. There's more signs that China's economy is slowing down. China's exports tumbled by 7.5 per cent from May last year amid weaker demand both at home and overseas. Imports contracted by an annual rate of 4.5 per cent, a slower pace of contraction, compared to the 7.9 per cent fall over the year to April. Official figures out last week showed China's manufacturing industry contracted for two months in a row. The latest numbers have spurred speculation of more stimulus spending by Chinese authorities. Iron ore prices rose in Singapore to $US107.80 a metric ton on the speculation. Beijing is also expected to further cut interest rates and the amount of reserves banks need to hold on their books to boost the economy. Chief economist at Pinpoint Asset Management, Zhiwei Zhang, told Reuters that China needs to rely on domestic demand as the global economy slows. "There is more pressure for the government to boost domestic consumption in the rest of the year, as global demand will likely weaken further in the second half."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: China's exports tumble

children.content: Let's take a look at some news other than Australia's economy.
There's more signs that China's economy is slowing down.
China's exports tumbled by 7.5 per cent from May last year amid weaker demand both at home and overseas.
Imports contracted by an annual rate of 4.5 per cent, a slower pace of contraction, compared to the 7.9 per cent fall over the year to April.
Official figures out last week showed China's manufacturing industry contracted for two months in a row.
The latest numbers have spurred speculation of more stimulus spending by Chinese authorities.
Iron ore prices rose in Singapore to $US107.80 a metric ton on the speculation.
Beijing is also expected to further cut interest rates and the amount
of reserves banks need to hold on their books to boost the economy.
Chief economist at Pinpoint Asset Management, Zhiwei Zhang, told Reuters that China needs to rely on domestic demand as the global economy slows.
"There is more pressure for the government to boost domestic consumption in the rest of the year, as global demand will likely weaken further in the second half."
